I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will strengthen judicial capacity in 
adjudicating commercial and environmental and climate change disputes in selected Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) developing member countries (DMCs); develop knowledge resources 
for  more  effective  and  efficient  adjudication  of  these  disputes;  and  foster  regional  judicial 
knowledge sharing and cooperation.1 The TA will build on ADB’s work with judiciaries over the 
years;2 and establish a more programmatic judicial capacity building program aligned with the 
development needs of the participating ADB DMCs.3 
 
2.  The TA supports ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priorities on strengthening governance 
and institutional capacity; tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and 
enhancing environmental sustainability; and fostering regional cooperation and integration.4 It is 
also in line with Strategy 2030’s goal of expanding private sector development. Further, the TA 
supports ADB DMCs’ commitments under the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 13 and 
16, particularly target 16.3 on the promotion of the rule of law to ensure equal access to justice; 
and target 16.6 on developing effective, accountable, and transparent institutions. 
 
II.  ISSUES  
 
3.  Strong and well-equipped judiciaries that uphold the rule of law are essential to ensuring 
that development goals are met in ADB DMCs. Strengthening the capacity of judiciaries can help 
encourage foreign and domestic investment and private sector development through the effective 
and efficient resolution of commercial disputes and enforcement of contracts. At the same time, 
judiciaries can positively affect sustainable development outcomes in ADB DMCs by interpreting 
and enforcing environmental and climate change laws and developing seminal jurisprudence that 
is responsive to sustainable development issues. Nevertheless, judiciaries across the region face 
significant challenges, ranging from inadequate resources to lack of expertise in complex and 
specialized areas of the law. 5 Additionally, the COVID-19 pandemic has put judiciaries under 
further pressure to increase efficiency while ensuring quality decisions and access to justice.  
 
4.  Adjudication of commercial disputes. There is a demonstrable need for commercial 
law judicial capacity building in many ADB DMCs where substantial reform efforts are taking place 
to increase private sector development and cross-border trade and foreign investments.6 Many 
judges in developing economies lack knowledge and experience in commercial law matters. 
Furthermore, commercial law judicial capacity is unevenly distributed among judiciaries despite 
the delivery of training by various development partners over the years. Consequently, the

adjudication of commercial matters in these courts has resulted in uncertainties in judicial 
decisions, lengthy contract enforcement, and higher transaction costs for parties, which ultimately 
deter investment and economic growth.  
 
5.  Moreover,  with  the  internationalization  of  commercial  transactions,  it  has  become 
essential to equip judges with an understanding of law in a transnational setting.7 The increasing 
multi-jurisdictional nature of legal disputes requires judicial readiness to handle complex cross-
border commercial disputes, as well as cross-border insolvency cases, which have become 
particularly relevant in the COVID-19 era.8 Additionally, judicial support for alternative dispute 
resolution and the application of best practices are required, e.g., in the enforcement of foreign 
arbitral awards, cross-border mediated settlement agreements, and foreign judgments. 
 
6.  Adjudication of environmental and climate change disputes. ADB DMCs have been 
prioritizing environmental protection and climate change issues as crucial development goals. 
They have established policies and enacted new or updated laws to address environmental 
issues, and more recently with the adoption of the Paris Agreement, to address climate change 
issues. Nevertheless, implementation and enforcement are weak and delayed. As a result, people 
have been increasingly turning to the courts to hold their governments and the private sector 
accountable.9 
 
7.  Many judiciaries in ADB’s DMCs face enormous challenges in adjudicating these highly 
complex and technical cases, which require them to balance economic, environmental, social, 
and cultural considerations and to devise appropriate and innovative remedies and damages. 10 
Since 2010, ADB has been providing capacity building in adjudicating environmental disputes to 
judiciaries in South Ais and Southeast Asia, and, since 2018, providing capacity building in 
adjudicating climate change cases to judiciaries in South Asia, Southeast Asia and Pacific DMCs. 
ADB’s sustained engagement has resulted in improved jurisprudence; the institutionalization of 
curricula in judicial academies; the establishment of green benches, e.g., Bhutan, Malaysia and 
Pakistan; the development of special rules of procedure for environmental cases, e.g., Bhutan 
and Philippines; and the creation of the Asian Judges Network on Environment (AJNE) which is 
supported by chief justices and high court judges from over 30 DMCs. 
 
8.  Despite these advances, judiciaries have called for ADB’s continuing support for capacity 
building programs, as well as the development of more targeted knowledge resources, e.g., on a 
particular issue such as remedies or on a specific issue relevant to a particular subregion. 
Additionally, judiciaries have requested greater access to case law or judgements from other 
jurisdictions and peer learning opportunities especially in adjudicating environmental and climate 
change cases with a transnational element. Moreover, there are certain DMCs such as Papua 
New Guinea and Thailand, looking to set up a separate environmental court and need assistance 
with its establishment, as well as related court procedures and training of specialized judges. 
 
7  Courts are faced with conflict of laws and jurisdictional issues which have taken on a new level of complexity and 
intensity. Additionally, judges can benefit from learning more about international conventions as disputes are 
increasingly subject to treaties, as well as international best practices.  
8   Numerous sources have projected that insolvencies will increase because of COVID-19. International Development 
Law Organization. Insolvency and COVID-19: A Crisis within a Crisis. 
9   For example, they have turned to the courts to ensure that governments implement or prepare appropriate climate 
responses. Additionally, rights-based lawsuits based on constitutional rights have been growing in these countries. 
ADB. 2020. Climate Change, Coming Soon to a Court Near You: Climate Litigation in Asia and the Pacific and 
Beyond. Manila. 
10 Many judges were not taught environmental and climate change laws in law school since these courses did not exist 
and they handle mainstream areas of law (e.g., civil, criminal and commercial law) but are now asked to hear 
environmental and emerging climate change cases.

3 
9.  Virtual adjudication best practices to increase access to justice. Due to the COVID-
19 pandemic, courts were forced to shut down and judiciaries had to rapidly introduce and adapt 
to various forms of remote hearings. Divergent practices and standards have been developed 
among the judiciaries in ADB DMCs, creating various access to justice issues such as ensuring 
impartiality, fairness and transparency. Additionally, many judges have found the transition from 
physical to remote hearings challenging. As courts continue their digitalization efforts which trend 
will continue beyond the COVID-19 pandemic, there is a need to include virtual adjudication best 
practices including discussions on which cases or hearings are best suited for remote hearings, 
as well as increase the digital literacy of judges as part of the judicial capacity building programs.11 
 
10.  Benefits of judicial capacity building. Judicial capacity building programs play an 
essential role in administering justice, and effectively and efficiently resolving disputes with 
enormous development impacts. Studies have shown that capacity building of judges facilitates 
the prompt resolution of disputes and can lead to higher quality judicial decisions.12 Capacity 
building can also foster greater uniformity and predictability of decisions, and can increase public 
confidence in the judicial system’s ability to deal effectively with specialized matters. Judiciaries 
with greater capacity can help maintain the rule of law through enduring principles and predictable 
processes, while also responding to a rapidly changing society. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: strengthened rule of law through independent, 
impartial, and skilled judiciaries (ADB’s Strategy 2030 OP 3, OP 6, OP 7; and SDGs 13 and 16, 
Paris Agreement). The TA will have the following outcome: improved capacity of judiciaries in 
adjudicating commercial and environmental and climate change disputes.13 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  The outputs of the TA are described in paras. 13–15. 14 
 
13.  Output  1:  Judicial  capacity  building  programs  and  knowledge  resources  on 
adjudication of commercial disputes developed. This output will deliver commercial law 
judicial capacity building in DMCs where substantial reform efforts are taking place to improve the 
business climate. In particular, it will help build on and implement business law reforms supported 
under ADB policy-based loans and TA, e.g., in Fiji, Palau, Papua New Guinea, and Uzbekistan 
where ADB has been assisting with international arbitration law reform; and in Armenia, Indonesia, 
and Myanmar where ADB has been supporting insolvency law reform. The output will (i) organize 
focus group discussions with judges, lawyers, businesses, and other stakeholders to assess 
judicial knowledge and skills gaps; (ii) conduct a needs assessment on capacity and institutional 
mechanisms  for  handling  commercial  disputes  in  the  relevant  courts  for  discussion  with 
implementing  agencies;  (iii)  design  and  deliver  tailored  commercial  law  capacity  building

programs, including on internationally accepted principles and standards, effective judgment 
writing and virtual adjudication best practices;15 and (iv) develop judicial training curricula and 
specialized knowledge resources such as bench books, guides, or manuals on commercial law 
adjudication. 
 
14.  Output  2:  Judicial  capacity  building  programs  and  knowledge  resources  on 
adjudication of environmental and climate change disputes developed. This output will build 
on the gains achieved under ADB’s environmental and climate change judicial capacity programs 
implemented in South Asia, Southeast Asia and Pacific DMCs (footnote 2). 16 It will (i) conduct a 
new  or  updated  needs  assessment  on  capacity  and  institutional  mechanisms  for  handling 
environmental and climate change disputes, and discuss the findings with the implementing 
agencies;  (ii)  design  and  deliver  tailored  capacity  building  programs  in  relevant  areas  of 
environmental, climate change, and other sustainable development issues, including on internally 
accepted  principles  and  standards,  effective  judgment  writing  and  virtual  adjudication  best 
practices (footnote 15); and (iii) develop targeted knowledge resources on specific issues such 
as remedies or issues relevant to a particular subregion such as the Greater Mekong Subregion. 
Additionally, if requested, assistance can be provided in the establishment of green benches or 
specialized  environmental  courts  and  the  development  of  special  rules  of  procedure  for 
environmental and/or climate change cases. 
 
15.  Output 3: Regional knowledge sharing and cooperation strengthened. The judicial 
capacity building programs will be further reinforced through the mutual exchange and cross-
pollination of best practices among the judiciaries and the judicial learning bodies of ADB DMCs. 
Moreover, the TA will work with regional  organizations such as the Asia-Pacific Economic 
Cooperation,  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations,  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic 
Cooperation Program and/or South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation to institutionalize 
the capacity building programs and support regional knowledge sharing.17 This output will (i) 
convene regional conferences in specialized areas of the law, as well as connect judiciaries with 
experts in related fields; (ii) produce knowledge products derived from the regional conference; 
(iii) leverage judicial networks to bring judges together in a smaller format to discuss common 
issues; (iv) build on existing regional judicial networks and knowledge platforms such AJNE, in 
particular, in increasing greater access to regional case law or court judgements; and (v) link 
judiciaries to international judicial networks such as GJIE and International Association of Women 
Judges. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund ($850,000 TASF-6 and $150,000 TASF-other sources).18 The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
15 The design, duration, and schedule of each judicial capacity building program will be discussed and agreed with the 
implementing agencies; and will vary according to each participating DMC. Additionally, on a pilot basis, a group of 
judges can be supported to become trainers under a train-the-trainers model to deliver trainings to other judges. 
16   ADB’s Central and West DMCs will be eligible to request assistance under Output 2, however, based on research, 
there is no reported environmental or climate change litigation (except Pakistan). Nevertheless, the lack of reported 
cases does not mean the region has no environmental or climate change cases. It is more likely that environmental 
and climate change litigation is minimal or nascent in these jurisdictions. 
17 For example, the TA can work with the Council of ASEAN Chief Justices Working Group on Judicial Education and 
Training. 
18 It  is  anticipated  that  additional funds  will  be  required  based  on  initial  requests from  DMCs and  a  4-year 
implementation period. Additional funding opportunities will be sought from other special funds and trust funds, 
including the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund, which has been informed of the TA.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB, through the Office of the General Counsel’s Law and Policy Reform Program, will 
be the executing agency and administer the TA. Implementing agencies will be the supreme 
courts, judicial academies, and judicial schools; and relevant ministries such as the ministries of 
justice. Target DMCs will be identified in consultation with relevant ADB regional departments, 
the Private Sector Operations Department, the Office of Public–Private Partnership, and sector 
and thematic groups.19 Additionally, ADB will collaborate with development partners—such as the 
United  Nations  Commission  on  International  Trade  Law;  the  International  Association  of 
Restructuring, Insolvency and Bankruptcy Professionals; the International Development Law 
Organization; the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development; the United States Agency 
for  International  Development;  the  International  Association  of  Women  Judges;  the  United 
Nations Environment Programme; and the GJIE—in delivering the capacity building programs, 
convening  knowledge  sharing  events,  and  disseminating  knowledge  products.  The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis, for 
Strengthening Judicial Capacity Towards Sustainable Economic Development in Asia and the 
Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
